comments.commentBody: Well, no, they'd be living in Palestine, as they had done before getting kicked out to create Israel.

J.,perhaps if the Palestinians and their allies ceased their aggression against Israel, Israel would respond in kind. It has never been tried before and, who knows, it might work!

The only way to find out is to give it a try!
People like Net an Yahoo are the ones that are more dangerous to Israel than the Palestinians he is suppressing. Every action of his weakens Israel not defends it.

And pray tell : Exactly where ARE Israel's boarders ? The River and The Sea ? The civilized countries of the world are running out of patience with The Jewish State's behavior . Israel had better wake up soon .
Perhaps the real messge is that we should not blindly support Isreal

Perhaps the real message of the election is not that Netanyahu's margin was diminished but that those parties who favor concessions that will weaken Israel's ability to defend itself and maintain defensible borders were weakened to the point of being virtually extinct.

Not exactly do we have freedom to choose our consumption patterns. The processed, fast-food and industrial food industries have done everything in their power to prevent us from being able to identify what is in their products, and how they're made. Even a minor amount of labeling was forced on them, and they continue to misinform with labels saying that foods are "natural" when that term has no definition They refuse to label genetically engineered foods, and this Fall spent millions in California to defeat a GMO labeling initiative. They fight any effort to label country of origin for meat. A number of years back they attempted to change the law governing what is considered "organic" to include irradiated foods, GMOs, and plants fertilized with human sewage sludge. They've got FDA to agree to call irradiated foods "cold processed". They refuse to reveal what milk, cheese or ice cream is made from cows treated with bovine growth hormone (which contains elevated levels of growth hormone).

I could go on, but you get the picture. You have to do a lot of research to be able to make real choices, which are informed choices. The food business is not providing us with what we want, they are providing us with what they want, even if it means lying about what we're getting.

Awsome movie I agree with others who gave it a 4 rating. From the reviews I see people love it or hate it no middle ground it seems. I attended with my Sister and I loved it and she hated it go figure. Her dislike was mostly the language. I did not find it offensive and she did. I liked the black humor and the very real feel of the struggles and disfunction. Yes there was humor at the expense of mental illness but I feel there was real human drama as well handled so expertly by Bradley. His choice of attire was really factual in feeling what a person with mental illness would do. Their chemistry was so palpable it made for great love story in the midst of real human dialog. One of the greats I feel esp with all the horrible movies being made today. Empty violent
nonsense where this is deep and viseral at times. Funny and
edgy at times but always very spot on with the acting and dialog.
Great job by all the actors I feel. I cannot wait to see this movie again.

Karen:  As usual, an excellent blog.  When 25% of the major corporations do not pay any taxes or even worse, receive tax refunds, we are doomed financially.  In essence, us little folks are expected to subsidize both the Wall Street thieves and corporations so that they can continue to take wealth from this once-great nation!
Why do so many people vote for the GOP

Thanks, Karen.
President Obama (for whom I voted twice ) said some eloquent words about equality and "little girls'" chances. BUT he and Michelle gave us their real views when they dressed their 11 year-old in a $400 dress for the ceremony Monday.
No many of the 99% women can afford that for themselves let alone fo an 11 year old child.

Just like 4 years ago, fine words opposite actions.

Let's not forget that we have a Dept. of Justice that has done little to nothing to redress the massive Wall Street fraud that has robbed Americans of trillions of dollars in household wealth. This failure to protect the economic rights of citizens constitutes a dereliction of duty so severe as to amount to a government co-conspiracy with the felons of the financial class.

The president soared to his usual oratorical heights. But to date, his inactions have spoken louder than his words. His current head of the DOJ criminal division, Lanny Breuer, is still insisting (most recently on PBS's "Frontline") that he can't punish the banks for fear that the whole global financial system would collapse. "Too big to fail and too big to jail" is the new rule in what has become a bleak land of two-tiered justice. The rich get richer, and the poor are imprisoned. And the jails are economic as well as physical. Too many people have been unfairly sentenced to chronic unemployment, lost homes, stagnating wages, and shortened lives.

And then there's the income inequality, which has only gotten worse in the last four years. We rank near the bottom of the heap in terms of social mobility. All three branches of government share the blame. Rather than heed our call for shared prosperity, they insist that we "share the sacrifice" and pay, through austerity, for the misdeeds of the same gluttons who continue to feed at the public trough.

http://kmgarcia2000.blogspot.com/

Dr. Heart : Arabs were also promised self rule in Palestine for their assistance against the Ottomans, instead this mandate of 1926 was a slap in their faces.
Western powers were anxious to create a "Jewish homeland" in Israel because they didn't want large populations of Jewish immigrations to their own countries (Truman papers 1948). A moderate immigration to Israel and a true democracy shared with the peoples who had lived there for thousands of years might have had a different outcome. Instead, millions were encouraged to come to Israel to push the gentile population aside with the notion that the Bible somehow gave them the right to TAKE whatever they wanted from any non-Jew no matter what their claim to property was, and forcing them into a living barely above that of a concentration camp, but more closely resembling a reservation, utterly dependent without a voice.

@ Dr. M

Drones aside, which I don't consider "meddling" as much as unethical and against all international treaties and accords, you are absolutely right: the US is the world's biggest "meddler" in the affairs of other countries.

So why should we meddle in Israel's favour?

"When an American presidential candidate visits Israel and his key message is to encourage us to pursue a misguided war with Iran, declaring it “a solemn duty and a moral imperative” for America to stand with our warmongering prime minister, we know that something profound and basic has changed in the relationship between Israel and the United States. ~ AVRAHAM BURG, former speaker of the Knesset

stevieby:

In case you DIDN'T notice, most American foreign aid is tied to purchases here in the US of A. Most of it turn into "make-work" for defense contractors.

By the way, the $3-4 BILLION we send to each of Israel and Egypt pays for about 1 to 2 weeks of the war in Afghanistan.

Israel's GNP is about $200 Billion a year, and Egypt's is about $500 Billion a year.

There are about 7.5 million Israelis (6 million Jews, about 1.5 million Arabs) and about 82 million Egyptians. Egypt - twice the income, 10 times the population -- doing GREAT, right??

The Afghanis are getting a lot more "foreign aid" that the Israelis and the Egyptions combined.

Get a grip.
A thorium fuel cell powering a lazer and using water.   I like it!  Let's spend a billion or so and start producing it.
Thorium fuel technology is an established energy technology that could contribute to reducing man made CO2 emission.
Your question would be relevant if we were talking about the manumission of enslaved imprisoned humans.

This has been a long, long time coming.  I'm so happy for these chimps & sad that it took this long.  I see this as a major step in the right direction for animal welfare.  Their lives are not OURS to do with as we please.  It's our obligation to protect beings that cannot protect themselves, not use and abuse them for our own selfish benefit.  Human beings are intellectually superior... therefore, we should be capable of achieving scientific advancement without needless cruelty.

A lot of commenters, with their tiresome jokes about Manhattan apartments, don't seem to realize that U.S. research chimps do NOT currently have 1,000 sq feet each as a standard living space. That figure is just a recommendation which may never be realized.
The reality is that research chimps are often kept in tiny cages with barely room to turn around!
From the article:
"The report also proposes standards for the social and physical welfare of N.I.H. chimps, including requirements that they live in groups of at least seven, have a minimum of 1,000 square feet per chimp, room to climb, access to the outdoors in all weather and opportunities to forage for food. 'Not a single laboratory in the United States meets these recommendations,' Ms. Conlee said."

Sorry but it is you who are ignorant of the reality of animal research. In the U.S. alone it consumes many millions of animals per year. It is full of redundancy and speculative unnecessary experiments which have little or no connection to human welfare.
And nobody who actually works with chimps is a "fan of the gentle chimp". Of course they are dangerous. Charla Nash's experience was the result of a powerful wild animal being placed in the wrong situation by ignorant people.
You appear to believe that only "gentle" harmless animals are "good" and deserve decent treatment. This attitude tends to disappear when a person studies and learns to appreciate natural systems and evolutionary forces.

You've had no replies all day, Roger - I think because most of us are not speed solvers.  The few times I've tried "PATC", it's been recorded a couple of seconds different from my clock, but I don't think I've tried it since the "reinvented" website.

Perhaps someone can tell me why, in "Play Against the Clock," the time to completion recorded at the top of the puzzle and that recorded in the "Fastest" table are so often different. I don't mean by a second or two, but, as in tonight's puzzle, by as many as 15 seconds. (The table always shows a slower time to finish.)

I reported this as a possible software glitch on the NYT puzzle e-mail form, but have never received a response.

Anyone else experience this?

I was a gymnast and ballet dancer from an early age, and a ferocious high-impact exercise devotee. Maybe that was a factor in the early, severe, arthritic condition of my hip. By the time I sought medical attention, I could barely walk, and I was in extreme pain. I had assumed I had a muscle issue. I was shocked to see the x-ray showing the degeneration.

I was thrilled to qualify for the BHR. I had a text book result, in San Francisco, with Dr. Peter Callander. I saw the post-op x-rays showing the perfect placement of the device. I was walking with assistance a few hours post-op (that is s-o-p) and I was driving within a week (yes, I was told to wait, but I was able to do it, so . . .). I do not know what a regular procedure would have entailed, but the BHR was a cake walk, and I am very, very grateful.
It is not any different under Dems. All the govt. folks cozy up to industry, looking to get high-paid jobs post-govt.

For starters you could read the blog for 6/10/2011 and follow the links

I "recommended" your comment. But...I have to ask you this based on your second sentence which reads:
"Isn't the foundation of christianity supposed to be abt love and tolerance for all?"
My question to you: How long have you had your head stuck in the sand abt religions' "love and tolerance for all"? (ALL religions I'd say)
Taxing churches is a terrific idea but it won't stop the hate and intolerance; for that to happen everyone needs to begin to search their own deeply-held beliefs (we all have them), see their destructive tendencies and end all beliefs of religion.
Now that would be a true man/woman of science -- enlightened with a free mind...

P

No, the foundation of Christianity is not "love and tolerance for all." It is, in fact, archaic paganistic goddess (and later pantheistic god) worship. The one part of this ancient tradition these dangerously misguided evangelicals are adhering to is the tendency for the religion to mutate and spread to areas where it hadn't previously been known, usually via conquests and migrations.

Probably this attempt to radically Christianize an entire African nation will have limited success. Let's hope at least that the inflow of money from American evangelicals to Africa will have some positive effect.

Yes start taxing churches. These hate groups are not just operating in Africa. Here in California the Mormons influenced our vote on prop 8 banning gay marriage. The Catholic church also preaches hate to its followers. Why should such political groups who use their money towards elections be tax free?

I find this sickening and frightening. Isn't the foundation of Christianity supposed to be about love and tolerance for all? I find the Christian church with it's "missionaries" to be nothing more than opportunistic blood suckers praying on the poor and uneducated. Wherever you find a population in dire need of healthcare, shelter, food, jobs, and education- gaurenteed you will find some religious group with a hidden agenda- attempting to empower people through the word of "god", when in reality they end up stripping a community (a nation) of it's cultural identity through hatred and fear.. As a moral free thinker, naturalist, believer in science, a loving father and husband my only hope is that one day we will stop the dumbing down of our society and put an end to these wolves in sheeps clothing- start taxing churches! Without the bible these people are nothing more than any other hate group.

fair comment, but do you really expect a scientific consensus to develop quickly around new research where one of the largest global companies would stand to suffer?

let's just say there is an emerging body of scientific study that is pointing to the difference in metabolism of glucose and fructose. they do rhyme, though.

I don't know about any other American cities, but since 1974 Pittsburgh has had a toy lending library for children up to age 6.  It's located in the Shadyside area of the city and is entirely run by volunteers.  It offers a play space, a reading space, and an art space as well as around 400 toys that can be borrowed and taken home.

I bought most of my children's toys and games from garage or yard sales, thrift shops, fundraising sales at schools, Salvation Army stores, or Goodwill and never spent more than a few dollars (they did receive new things from relatives and friends on birthdays, etc.) One of their favorite toys was a Sit 'n Spin purchased for $5 from Goodwill; other favorites were also under $5. Sales in affluent neighborhoods usually have the best finds.

A bit of a separate comment, although related, is that here in New Zealand most communities have Toy Libraries, which lend toys out just as a books are. Membership is usually around $40-$80 a year and they have everything from outdoor toys to puzzles to dress up clothes. As an American living abroad raising two small children, I am often the envy of my friends back home when they mention the cost of a new toy only to have me say, "oh yes, Ben loved that when we took it out from the toy library!". It allows us to escape the heaps of toys that have long become tiresome, while allowing our children to enjoy the 'it' toys of the moment. It's a shame that toys are now like so many other things in America culture - only for the rich. Hopefully stories like this will encourage more sharing and less buying. There would be so many benefits.
